  "article_text": [
    "given a finite dimensional hopf algebra @xmath0 and its dual @xmath3 drinfeld [ dr1 ] has introduced the quantum double @xmath8 as the universal hopf algebra extension of @xmath0 satisfying    1 .",
    "there exists a unital algebra embedding @xmath9 such that @xmath1 is algebraically generated by @xmath0 and @xmath10 .",
    "2 .   let @xmath11 be a basis with dual basis @xmath12 .",
    "then @xmath13 is quasitriangular .",
    "it follows that as a coalgebra @xmath14 , where `` cop '' refers to the opposite coproduct . however , when realized on @xmath2 , the algebraic structure of @xmath1 becomes more involved .",
    "it has been analyzed in detail by s.  majid as a particular example of his notion of double crossed products , see [ m3,m4 ] and references therein .",
    "the dual version of the quantum double has been introduced for infinite dimensional compact quantum groups in [ pw ] as the mathematical structure underlying the quantum lorentz group .    during the 90 s",
    "the quantum double has become of increasing importance as a quantum symmetry in two  dimensional lattice and continuum qft . in continuum theories the quantum double @xmath1 of a finite group @xmath15",
    "( i.e.  @xmath16 ) has first been applied ( mostly in a twisted version , which we will come back to below ) to describe the symmetry underlying the sector structure of orbifold models in [ dpr ] . quite interestingly",
    ", the same structure appears as a residual generalized `` dyon  symmetry '' in spontanously broken ( 2 + 1)-dimensional higgs models with a finite unbroken subgroup @xmath15 [ bawi ] . for the role of quantum doubles in integrable field theories",
    "see , e.g.  [ bl ] .",
    "more recently , in the framework of algebraic qft , m.  mger [ m ] has also found the double of a finite group @xmath15 acting as a global symmetry on a `` disorder  field extension '' @xmath17 of a massive 2dimensional field algebra @xmath18 with global gauge symmetry @xmath15 . as opposed to the above cases , in this type of models",
    "the `` disorder  part '' @xmath3 of the double is also spontaneously broken , corresponding to a violation of haag duality ( for double cones ) for the @xmath1invariant observable algebra @xmath19 .",
    "the haag dual extension @xmath20 is then recovered as the invariant subalgebra of @xmath17 under the unbroken symmetry @xmath15 .    on the lattice ,",
    "related but prior to mger s work , the double of a finite group @xmath15 has been realized by k.  szlachnyi and p.  vecsernys as a symmetry realized on the order@xmath21disorder field algebra of a @xmath15spin quantum chain [ szv ] . since for @xmath22 the double coincides with ( the group algebra of ) @xmath23 ,",
    "this generalizes the well known order@xmath21disorder symmetry of abelian @xmath15spin models .",
    "this investigation has been substantially extended to arbitrary finite dimensional @xmath24hopf algebras @xmath0 in [ nsz ] , where the authors show that such `` hopf spin models '' always have @xmath1 as a universal localized cosymmetry .",
    "this means that under the assumption of a haag dual vacuum representation ( i.e.  absence of spontanous symmetry breaking ) the full superselection structure of these models is precisely created by the irreducible representations of @xmath1 .",
    "the formulation of [ nsz ] also allowed for a generalization of duality transformations to the non  commutative and non  cocommutative setting .    as it has turned out meanwhile ,",
    "very much related results have been obtained independently for lattice current algebras on finite periodic lattice chains by a.  alekseev et al .",
    "[ affs ] . for these models",
    "the authors have completely determined the representation category , showing that it is in one - to - one correspondence with @xmath25 , where @xmath26 is the algebra living on a minimal loop consisting of one site and one link biting into its own tail . using the braided",
    " group theory of [ m5 ] ( see also [ m4 ] ) , it has been realized by one of us [ n1 ] , that @xmath26 is in fact again isomorphic to a quantum double @xmath1 . also , requiring @xmath0 to be a modular hopf algebra as in [ affs ]",
    ", the hopf spin model of [ nsz ] has been shown in [ n1 ] to be isomorphic to the lattice current algebra of [ affs ] by a local transformation of the generators , periodic hopf spin chains are meanwhile known to be isomorphic to @xmath27 , where @xmath28 depends on the length of the loop @xmath29 [ sz ] , thus explaining the representation theory of [ affs ] . ] . + as a common feature of all these models we emphasize that under the quantum physical requirement of positivity they only give rise to quantum symmetries with integer @xmath30dimensions [ n2 ] . by a perron ",
    "it also applies to the twisted double of [ dpr ] . ] .",
    "thus , to construct `` rational '' models with a finite sector theory and non ",
    "integer dimensions one is inevitably forced to depart from ordinary hopf algebras @xmath0 . here",
    ", the most fashionable candidates are the truncated semisimple versions of the @xmath30deformations @xmath31 , @xmath32 a simple lie algebra , at roots of unity , @xmath33 .",
    "also , since lattice current algebras have been invented as regularized verions of wznw  models [ affs , afsv , afs , bys , fa , fg ] , they should eventually be studied at roots of unity .",
    "following g.  mack and v.schomerus [ ms ] , truncated quantum groups at @xmath34 have to be described as _ weak quasi  hopf algebras _ in the sense of drinfeld [ dr2 ] , with the additional feature @xmath35 , where @xmath36 denotes the coproduct is also a quasi  hopf algebra but it still satisfies @xmath37 . ] .    to formulate lattice current algebras at roots of unity one",
    "may now combine the methods of [ affs ] with those developped by [ ags , as ] for lattice chern  simons theories .",
    "however , it remains unclear whether and how for @xmath38root of unity the structural results of [ affs ] survive the truncation to the semi - simple ( `` physical '' ) quotients .",
    "similarly , the generalizations of the model , the methods and the results of [ nsz ] to weak quasi quantum groups are by no means obvious . in particular",
    "one would like to know whether and in what sense in such models universal localized cosymmetries @xmath39 still provide coactions and whether @xmath0 would still be ( an analogue of ) a quantum double of a quasi - hopf algebra .",
    "in fact , a definition of a quantum double @xmath1 for quasi  hopf algebras @xmath0 has recently been proposed by s.  majid [ m2 ] .",
    "unfortunately this has only been done in form of an implicit tannaka ",
    "krein reconstruction procedure , which makes it hard to identify this algebra in terms of generators and relations in concrete models .",
    "+ in [ hn ] we have started a program where we generalize standard notions of hopf algebra theory ( like coactions and crossed products ) to ( weak ) quasi  hopf algebras and apply them to quantum chains based on weak quasi ",
    "quantum groups in the spirit of [ nsz , affs ] . as a central mathematical structure underlying these constructions",
    "we have developed the concept of a _ diagonal crossed product _ by the dual @xmath3 of a ( weak ) quasi  quantum group @xmath0 . in this way we have obtained as one of our main nontrivial examples an explicit algebraic definition of the double @xmath1 .",
    "we have shown that , as for ordinary hopf algebras , @xmath1 may be realized as a new quasi ",
    "bialgebra structure on @xmath2 . ] ( or , in the weak case , a certain subspace thereof ) containing @xmath40 as a sub - bialgebra .",
    "generalizing the results of [ nsz , affs ] we have also constructed the above lattice models for weak quasi ",
    "hopf algebras @xmath0 and established that they always admit localized coactions of @xmath1 in the sense of [ nsz ] .    in this work",
    "we extend our analysis of @xmath1 by proving that it is always a quasitriangular quasi ",
    "hopf algebra , which is weak if and only if @xmath41 . our main results are summarized by the following    * theorem a *    _ let @xmath42 be a finite dimensional quasi  hopf algebra with coproduct + @xmath36 , reassociator @xmath43 and invertible antipode @xmath44 .",
    "assume @xmath1 to be a quasi  hopf algebra extension @xmath8 satisfying _    * there exists a linear map @xmath45 such that @xmath1 is algebraically generated by @xmath0 and @xmath10 * @xmath46 is quasitriangular .",
    "* if @xmath47 and @xmath48 have the same properties , then their exists a bialgebra homomorphism @xmath49 restricting to the identity on @xmath0 and satisfying @xmath50 .",
    "then @xmath1 exists uniquely up to equivalence and the map @xmath51 given by is one of the two structural elements appearing in drinfeld s antipode axioms , see sect .  2.1 . ]",
    "@xmath52 provides a linear bijection .",
    "theorem a will be proven at the end of section 3.4 .",
    "we will also have a generalization to weak quasi ",
    "hopf algebras , which is stated as theorem  b in section  4 .",
    "the major achievement of theorem  a in comparison with [ hn ] consists in the construction of the antipode on @xmath1 to this end , as a central technical result we establish a formula for @xmath53 and the relations between @xmath54 , @xmath55 and @xmath56 for a quasitriangular @xmath57 in any quasi ",
    "hopf algebra @xmath0 .",
    "recall , that in ordinary hopf algebras the last three quantities coincide and therefore @xmath58 .    to prove these results we combine the methods of [ hn ] with the very efficient graphical calculus developed by [ rt , t , ac ] .",
    "this will also allow to give nice intuitive interpretations of many of our almost untraceable identities derived in [ hn ] .",
    "in fact , without this graphical machinery we would have been lost in proving or even only trying to guess these formulas . in particular , a purely algebraic proof of the formulas for @xmath54 and @xmath53 in theorem  2.1",
    "would most likely be unreadable and therefore also untrustworthy .",
    "this is why we think it worthwhile to put more emphasis on this graphical technique in the present paper .",
    "+ we start in section  2.1 with shortly reviewing drinfeld s theory of quasi  hopf algebras and introduce our graphical conventions in section  2.2 . in section  2.3",
    "we derive our main formulas for @xmath54 and @xmath53 for any quasi  triangular @xmath57 . in section  3.1",
    "we review our construction [ hn ] of the double @xmath1 as an associative algebra on the vector space @xmath2 . in section  3.2",
    "we reformulate this construction in the spirit of [ n1 ] in terms of the universal @xmath59flip operator @xmath60 .",
    "section  3.3 roughly sketches , how the double may also be realized on the vector space @xmath61 . in section  3.4",
    "we establish the quasi  triangular quasi  hopf structure of @xmath1 and prove theorem  a. finally , in section  3.5 we identify the category @xmath7 as the double of the category @xmath62 in the sense of [ m2 ] , thus proving that our construction of @xmath1 provides a concrete realization of majid s tannaka  krein like reconstruction procedure . in section  4",
    "we generalize our results to weak quasi ",
    "hopf algebras @xmath0 . as an application we discuss the twisted double @xmath63 of [ dpr ] in appendix  a and generalize the results of [ n1 ] on the relation with the monodromy algebras of [ ags , as ] in appendix  b. + throughout",
    ", all linear spaces are assumed finite dimensional over the field @xmath64 .",
    "we will use standard hopf algebra notations , see e.g. [ a , sw , k , m3 ] . by an extension @xmath65 of algebras",
    "we always mean a unital injective algebra morphism @xmath66 .",
    "two extensions @xmath67 and @xmath68 are called equivalent , if there exists an isomorphism of algebras @xmath69 restricting to the identity on @xmath70 .",
    "in this subsection we review the basic definitions and properties of quasitriangular quasi  hopf algebras as introduced by drinfeld [ dr2 ] , where the interested reader will find a more detailed discussion .",
    "a _ quasi - bialgebra _",
    "@xmath71 is an associative algebra @xmath0 with unity , algebra morphisms @xmath72 and @xmath73 , and an invertible element @xmath74 , such that @xmath75 the map @xmath59 is called the coproduct and @xmath76 the counit .",
    "a coproduct with the above properties is called _ quasi - coassociative _ and the element @xmath77 will be called the _",
    "reassociator_. the identities ( [ eq12 ] ) and ( [ eq14 ] ) together imply @xmath78    let us briefly recall some of the main consequences of these definitions for the representation theory of @xmath0 .",
    "let @xmath62 be the category of finite dimensional representations of @xmath0 , i.e. of pairs @xmath79 , where @xmath80 is a finite dimensional vector space and @xmath81 is a unital algebra morphism .",
    "we will also use the equivalent notion of a @xmath0module @xmath80 with multiplication @xmath82 . given two pairs @xmath83 , the coproduct allows for the definition of a tensor product @xmath84 by setting @xmath85 .",
    "the counit defines a one dimensional representation .",
    "equation ( [ eq13 ] ) says , that this representation is a left and right unit with respect to the tensor product , and ( [ eq11 ] ) says that given three representations @xmath86 , then @xmath87 with intertwiner @xmath88 .",
    "the meaning of ( [ eq12 ] ) is the commutativity of the pentagon @xmath89 where the arrows stand for the corresponding rebracketing intertwiners .",
    "for example the first one is given by @xmath90 .",
    "the diagram ( [ pent ] ) explains the name pentagon identity for equation ( [ eq12 ] ) .",
    "the importance of axiom ( [ eq12 ] ) lies in the fact , that in any tensor product representation the intertwiner connecting two different bracket conventions is given by a suitable product of @xmath77 s , as in ( [ pent ] ) .",
    "the pentagon identity then guarantees , that this intertwiner is independent of the chosen sequence of intermediate rebracketings .",
    "this is known as mac lanes coherence theorem [ ml ] .",
    "bialgebra @xmath0 is called _ quasi - hopf algebra _ ,",
    "if there is a linear antimorphism @xmath91 and elements @xmath92 satisfying ( for all @xmath93 ) @xmath94 here and throughout we use the notation @xmath95 and @xmath96 to simplify the notation , we will in the following also frequently suppress the summation symbol and write @xmath97 , @xmath98 , etc .",
    "the map @xmath44 is called an antipode .",
    "we will also always suppose that @xmath44 is invertible .",
    "note that as opposed to ordinary hopf algebras , an antipode is not uniquely determined , provided it exists .",
    "the antipode allows to define the ( left ) dual representation @xmath99 of @xmath100 , where @xmath101 is the dual space of @xmath80 , by @xmath102 , the superscript @xmath103 denoting the transposed map .",
    "analogously one defines a right dual representation @xmath104 , where @xmath105 and @xmath106 .",

    "the element @xmath4 is called the r - matrix .",
    "the above relations imply the quasi - yang - baxter equation @xmath116 and the property @xmath117 eq .",
    "( [ eq18 ] ) implies , that for any pair @xmath118 the two representations @xmath119 and @xmath84 are equivalent with intertwiner @xmath120 , where @xmath121 denotes the permutation of tensor factors in @xmath122 .",
    "imply the commutativity of two hexagon diagrams obtained by taking @xmath123 on both sides .",

    "we also introduce @xmath190 as the coalgebra anti - mophism dual to @xmath44 , i.e.  @xmath191 .    0.5 cm      in the following it will be useful to have a graphical notation for the identities and definitions given so far . the graphical calculus introduced below has been developed and used in many papers , e.g. [ rt , ac , t ] , mainly in the setting of ribbon  hopf algebras . formally speaking ,",
    "it consists of a functor from the braided monoidal category @xmath62 into a category of colored graphs . for an introduction into the category terminology see [ k ] , [ t ] .",
    "we will use the graphical notation to have a pictorial way to understand - and deduce - certain relations and identities between morphisms ( intertwiners ) in @xmath62 , which - written out algebraically - would look very complicated . by morphisms in @xmath192",
    "we mean elements @xmath193 , i.e. linear maps @xmath194 satisfying @xmath195 .",
    "as discussed in section 2.1 , the @xmath196fold tensor product of @xmath0modules is again a @xmath0module ( where one has to take care of the bracketing of the tensor factors ) .",
    "a morphism @xmath103 from an @xmath196-fold to an @xmath197-fold tensor product of @xmath0modules is represented by a graph consisting of a `` coupon '' with @xmath196 lower legs and @xmath197 upper legs `` coloured '' with the source and target modules respectively .",
    "the upper and lower legs are always equipped with a definite bracketing corresponding to the bracketing defining the associated tensor module .",
    "for example the picture    @xmath198 }   \\multiput(1,1)(2,0){4}{\\line(0,1){2 } }   \\put(0,3){\\framebox(8,2){$t$ } }   \\multiput(2,5)(2,0){3}{\\line(0,1){2 } }   \\put(2,7.5){\\makebox(0,0){$u$ } }   \\put(4,7.5){\\makebox(0,0){$v$ } }   \\put(6,7.5){\\makebox(0,0){$x$ } }   \\put(1.5,6 ) { ( } \\put(4.25,6 ) { ) } \\end{picture}\\ ] ]    corresponds to the morphism @xmath199 { \\longrightarrow}(u { \\otimes}v ) { \\otimes}x\\ ] ] the tensor product of two morphisms corresponds to the juxtaposition of diagrams and the composition of morphisms is depicted by gluing the corresponding graphs together .",
    "here one has to take care that the gluing @xmath200 is only admissible if source(@xmath103 ) = target(@xmath201 ) , which in particular implies that the bracketing conventions of the associated tensor factors have to coincide .",
    "we also use the convention that the lower legs always represent the source , i.e. the graph @xmath202 is obtained by gluing @xmath103 on top of @xmath201 .",
    "following the conventions of [ ac ] we now give a list of some special morphisms depicted by the following graphs : @xmath203 @xmath204 }    \\end{picture } } }     \\put(0,2.5){\\makebox(0,0){$v$ } }     \\put(2,2.5){\\makebox(0,0){${}^*v$ } }     \\put(3,1.75){:= }     \\put(5,1.25){\\framebox(4,1.5){$b_v$ } }     \\put(7,0){\\line(0,1){1.25 } }     \\multiput(6,2.75)(2,0){2}{\\line(0,1){1.25 } }     \\put(6,4.5){\\makebox(0,0){$v$ } }     \\put(8,4.5){\\makebox(0,0){${}^*v$ } }     \\put(7,-0.5){\\makebox(0,0){$\\mathbb{c}$ } }     \\put(9.5,1.75 ) { , }     \\end{picture }      \\begin{picture}(11,5 )     \\put(0,2 ) { {    \\begin{picture}(2,2)(0.25,0 )    \\put(1,0){\\oval(2,2)[t ] }    \\end{picture } } }     \\put(2,1.5){\\makebox(0,0){$v$ } }     \\put(0,1.5){\\makebox(0,0){${}^*v$ } }     \\put(3,1.75){:= }     \\put(5,1.25){\\framebox(4,1.5){$a_v$ } }     \\put(7,2.75){\\line(0,1){1.25 } }     \\multiput(6,0)(2,0){2}{\\line(0,1){1.25 } }     \\put(8,-0.5){\\makebox(0,0){$v$ } }     \\put(6,-0.5){\\makebox(0,0){${}^*v$ } }     \\put(7,4.5){\\makebox(0,0){$\\mathbb{c}$ } }     \\end{picture}\\ ] ] @xmath205 where @xmath64 stands for the one dimensional representation given by the counit and where @xmath206 here @xmath207 is a basis of @xmath80 with dual basis @xmath208 and @xmath209 denotes the permutation of tensor factors in @xmath210 .",
    "we also use the shortcut notation @xmath211 , @xmath212 , etc .",
    "the properties of @xmath0 being a quasitriangular quasi - hopf algebra ensure , that the above defined maps are in fact intertwiners ( morphisms of @xmath0-modules ) . note that within higher tensor products the graphs ( [ graf2 ] ) and ( [ graf3 ] ) are only admissible if their legs are `` bracketed together '' . in order to change the bracket convention one has to use rebracketing morphisms .",
    "these are given as products of the basic elements @xmath213 where each of the three individual legs in ( [ graf4 ] ) may again represent a tensor product of @xmath0modules . in this way we adopt the convention that any empty coupon with the same number of upper and lower legs - where the colouring only differs by the bracket convention - always represents the associated unique rebracketing morphism in @xmath62 given in terms of suitable products of @xmath77 s .",
    "we have already remarked that the uniqueness of this rebracketing morphism ( i.e. the independence of the chosen sequence of intermediate rebracketings ) is guaranteed by mclanes coherence theorem and the `` pentagon axiom '' ( [ eq12 ] ) .",
    "this is why it is often not even necessary to spell out one of the possible formulas for such an intertwiner .",
    "explicitly , the pentagon identity ( [ eq12 ] ) may be expressed as @xmath214 }    \\put(0,1){\\framebox(8,1 ) { } }    \\end{picture } } }    \\put(0,3 ) { {    \\begin{picture}(6,3)(0.25,0 ) \\put(0,1){\\framebox(8,1 ) { } }    \\end{picture } } }    \\end{picture}\\ ] ] as done in the above pictures we will frequently not specify the modules sitting at the source and target legs .",
    "also note that by eqs .. ( [ eq14 ] ) and ( [ eq15 ] ) the rebracketing of the ( invisible ) `` white '' leg corresponding to the trivial @xmath0module @xmath64 is always given by the trivial identification .",
    "if @xmath0 is finite dimensional , it may itself be viewed as a @xmath0-module under left multiplication and algebraic identities may directly be translated into identities of the corresponding graphs and vice versa .",
    "so e.g. eq .  ( [ eq17 ] ) is equivalent to @xmath217 }    \\end{picture } } }    \\put(1,2 ) { {    \\begin{picture}(2,2)(0.25,0 )    \\put(1,0){\\oval(2,2)[b ] }    \\end{picture } } }    \\put(5,1){\\line(0,1){1 } }    \\put(7,3.25){= }     \\put(8.5,1){\\line(0,1){5 } }    \\put(9.5,3.25){= }     \\put(11,2 ) { {    \\begin{picture}(6,3)(0.25,0 )    \\multiput(1,2)(2,0){3}{\\line(0,1){1 } }    \\multiput(1,0)(2,0){3}{\\line(0,1){1 } }    \\put(0,1){\\framebox(6,1 ) { } }    \\put(0.5,2.5 ) { ( }    \\put(2.5,0.25 ) { ( }    \\put(5.25,0.25 ) { ) }    \\put(3.25,2.5 ) { ) }    \\end{picture } } }    \\put(12,5 ) { {    \\begin{picture}(2,2)(0.25,0 )    \\put(1,0){\\oval(2,2)[t ] }    \\end{picture } } }    \\put(16,5){\\line(0,1){1 } }    \\put(14,2 ) { {    \\begin{picture}(2,2)(0.25,0 )    \\put(1,0){\\oval(2,2)[b ] }    \\end{picture } } }    \\put(12,1){\\line(0,1){1 } }    \\end{picture}\\ ] ] and eqs .",
    "( [ eq14 ] ) and ( [ eq15 ] ) together with imply @xmath218 }     \\put(2.25,3 ) { [ ( }     \\put(7.25,3 ) { ] }     \\put(5.25,3 ) { ) }     \\put(0,1.5){\\framebox(8,1 ) { } }     \\put(3,3.5 ) { {    \\begin{picture}(2,2)(0.25,0 )    \\put(1,0){\\oval(2,2)[t ] }    \\end{picture } } }     \\put(10,2){= }      \\multiput(12,1)(2,0){4}{\\line(0,1){1 } }     \\multiput(12,2)(6,0){2}{\\line(0,1){1 } }      \\put(14,2 ) { {    \\begin{picture}(2,2)(0.25,0 )    \\put(1,0){\\oval(2,2)[t ] }    \\end{picture } } }       \\put(11.5,1.25 ) { [ }     \\put(13.5,1.25 ) { ( }     \\put(16.25,1.25 ) { ) ] }   \\end{picture}\\ ] ] and @xmath219 }     \\put(0.5,3 ) { ( }     \\put(4.5,3 ) { ( }     \\put(7.25,3 ) { ) }     \\put(3.25,3 ) { ) }     \\put(0,1.5){\\framebox(8,1 ) { } }     \\put(5,3.5 ) { {    \\begin{picture}(2,2)(0.25,0 )    \\put(1,0){\\oval(2,2)[t ] }    \\end{picture } } }     \\put(10,2){= }      \\multiput(12,1)(2,0){4}{\\line(0,1){1 } }     \\multiput(12,2)(2,0){2}{\\line(0,1){1 } }      \\put(16,2 ) { {    \\begin{picture}(2,2)(0.25,0 )    \\put(1,0){\\oval(2,2)[t ] }    \\end{picture } } }       \\put(13.5,1.25 ) { [ }     \\put(15.5,1.25 ) { ( }     \\put(18.25,1.25 ) { ) ] }   \\end{picture}\\ ] ] as well as the upside  down and left ",
    "right mirror images of ( [ graf5b ] ) and ( [ graf5c ] ) and the graphs obtained by rotating by @xmath220 in the drawing plane . in general , with every graphical rule , where the graph is build from elementary graphs of the above list , the rotated as well as the upside  down and left ",
    "right mirror images are also valid and are proven analogously .",
    "this induces a @xmath221 - symmetry action on all graphical identities given below , which in fact is already apparent in the axioms of a quasi  triangular quasi ",
    "hopf algebra given in section 2.1 by taking @xmath222 , @xmath223 or @xmath224 instead of @xmath0 .",
    "finally we point out the important _ `` pull through '' _ rule saying that morphisms built from representation matrices of special elements in @xmath0 ( like the braiding ( [ graf3 ] ) or the reassociator ( [ graf4 ] ) ) always `` commute '' with all other intertwiners in the appropriate sense i.e. by changing colours and orderings accordingly .",
    "for example one has    @xmath225 } \\put(5.5,0.25){]}\\put(0.5,0.25 ) { [ }    \\put(0,1){\\framebox(8,1 ) { } }    \\end{picture } } } \\multiput(13,3)(6,0){2}{\\line(0,1){4 } } \\put(14,3 ) { {    \\begin{picture}(4,6)(0.25,0 )       \\put(0,1.25){\\framebox(4,1.5){$h'$ } }     \\put(2,2.75){\\line(0,1){1.25 } }     \\multiput(1,0)(2,0){2}{\\line(0,1){1.25 } }     \\put(3,-0.5){\\makebox(0,0){$$ } }     \\put(1,-0.5){\\makebox(0,0){$$ } }     \\put(2,4.5){\\makebox(0,0){$$ } }    \\end{picture }    } } \\put(15.5,6.25 ) { ( } \\put(19.25,6.25 ) { ) } \\put(21.5,4){= } \\multiput(24,0)(6,0){2}{\\line(0,1){4 } } \\put(25,0 ) { {    \\begin{picture}(4,6)(0.25,0 )       \\put(0,1.25){\\framebox(4,1.5){$h'$ } }     \\put(2,2.75){\\line(0,1){1.25 } }     \\multiput(1,0)(2,0){2}{\\line(0,1){1.25 } }     \\put(3,-0.5){\\makebox(0,0){$$ } }     \\put(1,-0.5){\\makebox(0,0){$$ } }     \\put(2,4.5){\\makebox(0,0){$$ } }    \\end{picture }    } } \\put(23.5,0.5 ) { [ } \\put(25.5,0.5 ) { ( } \\put(28.25,0.5 ) { ) ] }    \\put(23,5){\\framebox(8,1 ) { } }    \\multiput(24,4)(3,0){2}{\\line(0,1){1 } }    \\multiput(24,6)(3,0){2}{\\line(0,1){1 } }    \\put(30,4){\\line(0,1){1 } }    \\put(30,6){\\line(0,1){1 } }    \\put(23.5,4.25 ) { ( }    \\put(26.5,6.5 ) { ( }    \\put(30.25,6.5 ) { ) }    \\put(27.25,4.25 ) { ) }    \\end{picture}\\ ] ]    in the language of categories this means that the braidings and the reassociators provide _ natural transformations _ [ ml ] .      in this subsection",
    "we exploit the full power of our graphical machinery by proving various important identities involving the action of the antipode on a quasitriangular r  matrix .",
    "we recall that for ordinary hopf algebras ( i.e. where @xmath226 and @xmath227 are trivial ) one has @xmath228 and @xmath58 . to generalize these identities to the quasi ",
    "hopf case we introduce the following four elements in @xmath229 ( using the notation ) @xmath230 these elements have already been considered by [ dr2,s ] , see also eqs .",
    "( 9.20)-(9.23 ) of [ hn ] .",
    "they obey the commutation relations ( for all @xmath231 ) @xmath232 = p_{\\lambda}\\ , [ { { \\bf 1}}{\\otimes}a ] , \\quad\\quad &    { \\delta}({a_{(1)}})\\ , p_\\rho\\ , [ { { \\bf 1}}{\\otimes}s({a_{(2 ) } } ) ] = p_\\rho\\ , [ a { \\otimes}{{\\bf 1 } } ] \\\\    [ s({a_{(1)}}){\\otimes}{{\\bf 1}}]\\ , q_{\\lambda}\\ , { \\delta}({a_{(2 ) } } ) = [ { { \\bf 1}}{\\otimes}a]\\ , q_{\\lambda } , \\quad\\quad &    [ { { \\bf 1}}{\\otimes}{s^{-1}}({a_{(2)}})]\\,q_\\rho\\ , { \\delta}({a_{(1 ) } } ) = [ a{\\otimes}{{\\bf 1}}]\\ , q_\\rho \\end{split}\\ ] ] see e.g. [ hn , lem .  9.1 ] .",
    "a graphical interpretation of these identities will be given in eqs .",
    "( [ grafpq ] ) below . with these definitions",
    "we now have    [ ss ] let @xmath233 be a finite dimensional quasi ",
    "hopf algebra , let @xmath234 be as in and let @xmath107 be quasitriangular .",
    "then @xmath235 \\cdot [ ( s{\\otimes}{{\\rm id}})(q^{op}_\\rho\\,r ) ] \\cdot    [ ( r^i{\\otimes}q^i ) \\,{\\delta}^{op}(z^j ) ] \\notag\\\\         \\label{graf7a }     = & [ { \\delta}(r^j)\\ , ( y^i { \\otimes}z^i ) ] \\cdot [ ( { { \\rm id}}{\\otimes}{s^{-1}})(r \\ ,    p_\\rho)]\\cdot [ { { \\bf 1}}{\\otimes}{s^{-1}}(\\alpha q^j x^i)p^j ] \\\\      \\label{graf8a }       ( s{\\otimes}s)(r)\\ , \\gamma   = & \\gamma^{21 } \\,r \\end{aligned}\\ ] ]    a direct implication of equation is the following formula , which has already been stated without proof in [ ac ] .",
    "[ corfrf ] under the conditions of theorem [ ss ] let @xmath236 be the twist defined in , then @xmath237    using the formula ( [ eq118 ] ) for @xmath167 and ( [ graf8a ] ) one computes @xmath238    to prepare the proof of theorem [ ss ] we need the following 3 lemmata .",

    "the identity @xmath296 }   \\put(9.25,1.25){\\ } }    \\multiput(1,0)(2,0){3}{\\line(0,1){2 } }    \\multiput(7,1)(2,0){2}{\\line(0,1){1 } }    \\put(7,1 ) { {    \\begin{picture}(2,2)(0.25,0 )     "0.5 cm      in this section we review the definition of the double @xmath1 of a quasi  hopf algebra @xmath0 as a diagonal crossed product as introduced in [ hn ] .",
    "we also give a graphical description of this construction .",
    "consider @xmath299 and let @xmath300 be given by @xmath301\\ , [ \\phi{\\otimes}{{\\bf 1}}{\\otimes}{{\\bf 1}}]\\ ,              [ ( \\delta { \\otimes}{{\\rm id}}{\\otimes}{{\\rm id}})(\\phi^{-1})].\\ ] ] then the pair @xmath302 provides a _ two  sided coaction _ of @xmath0 on itself as defined in [ hn ] , i.e the following axioms are satisfied :    * the map @xmath258 is a unital algebra morphism satisfying @xmath303 . *",
    "the element @xmath300 is invertible and fulfills @xmath304    next we define @xmath305 by @xmath306 where @xmath307 are the twists defined in and .",
    "let now @xmath3 be the coalgebra dual to @xmath0 with its natural left and right @xmath0action and the nonassociative multiplication given by @xmath308 . with @xmath309 being a two  sided coaction",
    "we then write @xmath310 . note that for the two  sided coaction @xmath258 in eq .",
    "we have the identity @xmath311 . considered as an element of @xmath3 we also write @xmath312 .",
    "the following proposition has been proven in [ hn ] :    [ prop311 ] let @xmath302 be a two  sided coaction of @xmath0 on @xmath0 and define the diagonal crossed product @xmath313 to be the vector space @xmath2 with multiplication rule @xmath314 \\reli    \\big[{\\omega}^3 ( \\hat{s}^{-1}(\\psi_{(1)})\\re a \\li \\psi_{(3)})\\ , b \\big],\\ ] ] where we write @xmath315 in place of @xmath316 to distinguish the new algebraic structure .",
    "then @xmath313 is an associative algebra with unit @xmath317 , containing @xmath318 as a unital subalgebra .",
    "the associativity of the above product follows from the axioms for two  sided coactions as has been proven in theorem 10.2 of [ hn ] .",
    "note that in general the subspace @xmath319 is * not * a subalgebra of @xmath320 . on the other hand if @xmath0 is an ordinary hopf algebra with @xmath321 then eq",
    ".   becomes @xmath322 which is the standard multiplication rule in the quantum double @xmath1 [ dr1,m3 ] .",
    "this motivates the    [ double ] [ hn ] the diagonal crossed product @xmath320 defined in proposition [ prop311 ] , with @xmath302 given by , is called the * quantum double * of @xmath0 , denoted by @xmath323 .",
    "we will now rewrite the multiplication given in proposition [ prop311 ] using the `` generating matrix '' formalism of the st .",
    "petersburg school . in this way",
    "we will be able to give a graphical ( i.e. a categorical ) description of the algebraic relations in @xmath313 which should convince the reader , that the multiplication given in is indeed associative .",
    "the following corollary is a generalization of [ n , lemma 5.2 ] and coincides with [ hn , cor.10.4 ] applied to the present scenario .",
    "[ lem3.3 ] [ hn ] let @xmath70 be some unital algebra and @xmath324 a unital algebra map .",
    "then the relation @xmath325 provides a one to one correspondence between unital algebra morphisms @xmath326 extending @xmath250 and elements @xmath327 satisfying @xmath328 and @xmath329\\,{{\\rm \\bf l}^{}}&= [ { s^{-1}}(a_{(1)}){\\otimes}{{{{\\bf 1}}}_{{\\ensuremath{{\\cal a}}}}}]\\,{{\\rm \\bf l}^{}}\\,[a_{(-1)}{\\otimes}\\gamma ( a_{(0 ) } ) ] , \\quad \\forall a \\in { \\ensuremath{{\\cal g}}}\\\\     \\label{e315 } { { \\rm \\bf l}^{13}}{{\\rm \\bf l}^{23 } } & =   [ { \\omega}^5   { \\otimes}{\\omega}^4   { \\otimes}{{{{\\bf 1}}}_{{\\ensuremath{{\\cal a } } } } } ]        [ ( { \\delta}{\\otimes}{{\\rm id}})({{\\rm \\bf l}^ { } } ) ]                      [ { \\omega}^1 { \\otimes}{\\omega}^2 { \\otimes}\\gamma ( { \\omega}^3)],\\end{aligned}\\ ] ] where @xmath330 has been defined in and where @xmath331 .",
    "an element @xmath327 satisfying @xmath328 and ( [ e314]/[e315 ] ) is called a _",
    "normal coherent ( left diagonal ) @xmath258implementer _ ( with respect to @xmath250 ) , see [ hn ] .",
    "note that by choosing @xmath332 and @xmath333 , cor .",
    "[ lem3.3 ] implies that the multiplication on @xmath313 may uniquely be described by the relations of one `` generating matrix '' @xmath334 , where @xmath335 is a basis in @xmath0 with dual basis @xmath336 .",
    "in fact this formulation is used in [ hn ] to prove the associativity of the multiplication .",

we have used a pull through rule to push the lower @xmath346fork up and then we have combined all rebracketing morphisms in one box .",
    "now plugging in eq .",
    ", splitting the rebracketing morphism at the bottom into four factors and pushing two of them up , one obtains +   + l.h.s .",

    "we are now in the position to prove theorem a.    first note that corollary [ cor31 ] already proves the existence parts ( i),(ii ) of theorem a by putting @xmath510 . the fact that @xmath51 provides a linear isomorphism follows from the last statement in theorem [ thm31 ] . moreover , if @xmath511 is another hopf algebra extension and if @xmath512 is a linear map such that @xmath513 is algebraically generated by @xmath0 and @xmath514 and @xmath515 is quasitriangular , then @xmath516 @xmath517 is a uniquely and well defined algebra map satisfying @xmath518 by prop .",

    "thus @xmath1 also solves the universality property ( iii ) of theorem a. in particular the extension @xmath521 is unique up to equivalence",
    ".      we will now give a representation theoretical interpretation of the quantum double @xmath1 by describing its representation category in terms of the representation category of the underlying quasi - hopf algebra @xmath0 .",
    "in this way we will show that @xmath1 is a concrete realization of the quantum double as defined by majid in [ m2 ] with the help of a tannaka - krein - like reconstruction theorem .",
    "we denote the monoidal category of finite dimensional unital representations of @xmath1 and of @xmath0 by @xmath7 and @xmath62 , respectively .",
    "the next proposition states a necessary and sufficient condition , under which a representation of @xmath0 extends to a representation of @xmath1 :    @xmath471 + [ thm32 ] 1 . ) the objects of @xmath7 are in one to one correspondence with pairs @xmath523 , where @xmath79 is a finite dimensional representation of @xmath0 and where @xmath524 is a normal coherent @xmath59-flip , i.e.    1 .",
    "@xmath525 2 .",
    "@xmath526 3 .",
    "@xmath527 , where @xmath528 .    2 .",
    ") let @xmath523 and @xmath529 be as above , then @xmath530    we define the extended representation @xmath531 on the generators of @xmath1 by @xmath532 condition ( i ) implies that @xmath533 is unital whereas conditions ( ii),(iii ) just reflect the defining relations ( [ eq32 ] ) and ( [ eq33 ] ) of @xmath1 , which ensures , that @xmath533 is a well defined algebra morphism . on the other hand , given a representation @xmath534 of @xmath1 , we define @xmath535 which clearly satisfies conditions ( i ) - ( iii ) .",
    "this proves part  1 .",
    "follows trivially .    to get the relation with majid s formalism [ m2 ] we now write @xmath536 and define @xmath537 . with this notation",
    "we get the following corollary :    the conditions ( i)-(iii ) of proposition [ thm32 ] are equivalent to the following three conditions for @xmath538 ( as before denoting @xmath539 ) :    * @xmath540 * @xmath541 * @xmath542 + @xmath543,\\quad \\forall v \\in v$ ]    the equivalences ( i ) @xmath287 ( i ) and ( ii ) @xmath287 ( ii ) are obvious .",
    "the equivalence ( iii ) @xmath287 ( iii ) follows by multiplying ( iii ) with @xmath544 from the left and with @xmath545 from the right and permuting the first two tensor factors .",
    "the conditions stated in the above corollary agree with those formulated in [ m2 , prop.2.2 ] by taking @xmath546 instead of @xmath547 as the underlying quasi - bialgebra .",
    "this means that we have identified the category @xmath7 with what is called the double category of modules over @xmath0 in [ m2 ] .",
    "allowing the coproduct @xmath59 to be non  unital ( i.e.  @xmath548 ) leads to the definition of _ weak quasi ",
    "hopf algebras _ as introduced by g.  mack and v.  schomerus in [ ms ] . in this section",
    "we sketch how the construction of the quantum double @xmath1 generalizes to this case .",
    "as it will turn out , there are only minor adjustments to be made .",
    "the reason for this lies in the fact , that we have used mostly graphical identities ( i.e.  identities in @xmath62 ) to derive and describe our results .",
    "but since @xmath62 is a rigid monoidal category also in the case of _ weak _ quasi  hopf algebras @xmath0 , all graphical identities in section 2.2 and 2.3 stay valid .",
    "thus the only adjustements required refer to those points , where we have translated graphical identities into algebraic ones .",
    "+ following [ ms ] we define a _ weak quasi  hopf algebra _ @xmath549 to be an associative algebra @xmath0 with unit @xmath115 , a non  unital algebra map @xmath36 , an algebra map @xmath550 and an element @xmath551 satisfying - ,",
    "whereas is replaced by @xmath552 and where in place of invertibility @xmath77 is supposed to have a _ quasi  inverse _ @xmath553 with respect to the intertwining property . by this",
    "we mean that @xmath554 satisfies @xmath555 , @xmath556 as well as @xmath557 which implies the further identities @xmath558 more generally we call an element @xmath559 an intertwiner between two ( possibly non  unital ) algebra maps @xmath560 , if @xmath561 in this case by a quasi  inverse of @xmath103 ( with respect to this intertwiner property ) we mean the unique ( if existing ) element @xmath562 satisfying @xmath563 , @xmath564 and @xmath565 . note that this implies @xmath566 and therefore @xmath103 is also the quasi  inverse of @xmath567 .    a weak quasi  bialgebra is called _ weak quasi ",
    "hopf algebra _",
    ", if there exists a unital algebra antimorphism @xmath568 and elements @xmath569 satisfying and . we will also always suppose that @xmath44 is invertible .",
    "furthermore , @xmath0 is said to be quasitriangular if there exists an element @xmath570 satisfying  and possessing a quasi ",
    "inverse @xmath571 with respect to the intertwining property .    with these substitutions theorem a generalizes as follows    * theorem b",

    "assume @xmath8 to be a weak quasi ",
    "hopf algebra extension satisfying ( i)-(iii ) of theorem  a. then @xmath1 exists uniquely up to equivalence and the linear map @xmath51 @xmath573 is surjective with @xmath574 , where @xmath575 is the linear projection @xmath576 _    to adapt our previous strategy to weak quasi ",
    "hopf algebras we first recall that due to the coproduct being non  unital the definition of the tensor product functor in @xmath62 has to be slightly modified . first note that the element @xmath577 ( as well as higher coproducts of @xmath115 ) is idempotent and commutes with all elements in @xmath578 .",
    "thus , given two representations @xmath579 , the operator @xmath580 is a projector , whose image is precisely the @xmath0invariant subspace of @xmath210 on which the tensor product representation operates non trivial .",
    "thus one is led to define the tensor product @xmath581 of two representations of @xmath0 by setting @xmath582 one readily verifies that with these definitions @xmath125 - restricted to the subspace @xmath583 - furnish a natural family of isomorphisms defining an associativity constraint for the tensor product functor @xmath581 , where the tensor product of morphisms is defined by restricting the `` usual '' tensor product map to the truncated subspace .    with these adjustments , the graphical calculus described in section 2.2 and 2.3 carries over to the present case .",
    "the collection of colored upper ( or lower ) legs represent the ( truncated ) tensor product of @xmath0modules associated with the individual legs .",
    "one just has to take care when translating the pictures into algebraic identities .",
    "for example the graph @xmath584 is a pictorial representation of @xmath577 and not of @xmath585 ! thus the graph is equivalent to the algebraic identity @xmath586\\ , q_{\\lambda}\\ , { \\delta}(p^2_{\\lambda } ) = { \\delta}({{\\bf 1}})$ ] in place of the first equation of , etc . in this way",
    "all graphical identities of section 2 stay valid as well as theorem [ ss ] , where now @xmath54 is meant to be the quasi  inverse of @xmath4 .",
    "+ the definition of the diagonal crossed product in proposition [ prop311 ] yields an associative algebra which in general is not unital , but @xmath587 is still a right unit and in particular idempotent [ hn , thm .",
    "this may be cured by taking the right ideal generated by @xmath587 .",
    "thus , let @xmath588 be the linear projection given by left multiplication with @xmath589 with respect to the algebra structure , i.e. @xmath590 as in [ hn , sect",
    ".  14 ] we introduce the notation @xmath591 and define the quantum double @xmath1 as the subalgebra @xmath592 then @xmath593 is the unit of @xmath1 and in terms of the notation the multiplication in @xmath1 is still given by .",
    "in particular @xmath594 still provides a unital algebra inclusion . interpreting eq . also via , corollary [ lem3.3 ] likewise extends to the present scenario .",
    "however note that now the definition for left diagonal @xmath258implementers @xmath327 also implies the nontrivial relation @xmath595\\,{{\\rm",

    "as an application we now use theorem [ thm31 ] and theorem [ thm31a ] to recover the `` twisted '' quantum double @xmath617 of [ dpr ] where @xmath15 is a finite group and @xmath618 is a normalized 3-cocycle . by definition this means @xmath619 whenever at least one of the three arguments is equal to the unit @xmath620 of g and @xmath621 the hopf algebra @xmath622 of functions on @xmath15 may then also be viewed as a quasi - hopf algebra with its standard coproduct , counit and antipode but with reassociator given by @xmath623 where @xmath624 .",
    "the identities ( [ eq12 ] ) and ( [ eq14 ] ) for @xmath77 are equivalent to @xmath625 being a normalized 3-cocycle . also note that choosing @xmath626 the antipode axioms now require @xmath627 . in this special example",
    "our quantum double @xmath628 allows for another identification with the linear space @xmath2 .",
    "[ lema1 ] let @xmath0 be as above and define @xmath629 by @xmath630 .",
    "then @xmath631 is a linear bijection .",
    "since @xmath632 is also an ordinary hopf algebra , the relation is equivalent to ( suppressing the symbol @xmath436 ) @xmath633 using this implies @xmath634 which lies in the image of @xmath631 .",
    "hence , @xmath631 is surjective and therefore also injective .",
    "we note that in general the map @xmath631 need not be surjective ( nor injective ) . due to lemma [ lema1 ]",
    "we may now identify @xmath1 with the new algebraic structure on @xmath2 induced by @xmath635 .",
    "we call this algebra @xmath636 . putting @xmath637 and @xmath638",
    "it is described by the relations , ( [ eq33 ] ) and the requirement of @xmath639 being a unital subalgebra . to compute these multiplication rules",
    "we now use that the group elements @xmath640 provide a basis in @xmath3 with dual basis @xmath641 .",
    "hence a basis of @xmath636 is given by @xmath642 .",
    "in this basis the generating matrix @xmath377 is given by @xmath643 let us know compute the multiplication laws according to the definitions in theorem [ thm31 ] .",
    "to begin with , we have @xmath644 taking @xmath645 of both sides of ( [ eq32 ] ) , where @xmath646 , and using @xmath647 we get @xmath648 or equivalently @xmath649 finally , pairing equation ( [ eq33 ] ) with @xmath650 in the two auxiliary spaces , the l.h.s .",
    "yields @xmath651 where we have used ( [ eq318 ] ) in the first equality .",
    "the right hand side of ( [ eq33 ] ) gives @xmath652 so that we end up with @xmath653 similarly the coproduct is computed as @xmath654 and @xmath655 the above construction agrees with the definition of @xmath617 given in [ dpr ] up to the convention , that they have build @xmath1 on @xmath61 instead of @xmath2 .",
    "the definition of monodromy algebras ( see e.g. [ affs ] ) associated with quasitriangular hopf algebras may now easily be generalized to the case of quasi - hopf algebras .",
    "this has already been done in [ ags ] .",
    "we will give an explicit proof that the defining relations of [ ags ] indeed define an associative algebra structure on @xmath2 , which in fact is isomorphic to our quantum double @xmath1 .",
    "for ordinary hopf algebras this has recently been shown in [ n1 ] .",
    "let @xmath0 be a finite dimensional quasi - hopf algebra with quasitriangular r - matrix @xmath57 .",
    "following [ n1 ] we define the monodromy matrix @xmath656 to be @xmath657 defining also @xmath658 by @xmath659 we get the following lemma :      we will freely suppress the embedding @xmath436 . since the r - matrix has the property @xmath662 , equation ( [ eq328 ] ) follows from @xmath663 .",
    "the identity is implied by and the intertwiner property of the r  matrix .",
    "let us now compute the l.h.s . of ( [ eq330 ] ) : @xmath664^{132 } \\,{{\\rm \\bf d}^{23 } }      \\\\      & = \\big[(r{\\otimes}{{\\bf 1 } } ) \\cdot ( { \\delta}{\\otimes}{{\\rm id}})(r)\\big]^{312 }           \\,{{\\rm \\bf d}^{13}}\\,{(\\phi_{}^{-1})^{132}}\\,{{\\rm \\bf d}^{23 } }    \\end{aligned}\\ ] ] where we have used the quasitriangularity of @xmath4 in the second line and property ( [ eq32 ] ) of @xmath377 in the third line . the r.h.s . of ( [ eq330 ] )",
    "yields @xmath665^{312 } \\ ,         { { \\rm \\bf d}^{13}}\\ , { ( \\phi_{}^{-1})^{132}}{{\\rm \\bf d}^{23 } } ,    \\end{aligned}\\ ] ] where we have used the definitions of @xmath660 and @xmath666 and ( [ eq33 ] ) .",
    "now , the quasitriangularity of @xmath4 implies @xmath667 which finally proves ( [ eq330 ] ) .",
    "note that the relations - are precisely the defining relations postulated by [ ags ] to describe the algebra generated by the entries of a monodromy matrix around a closed loop together with the quantum group of gauge transformations sitting at the initial ( @xmath347 end ) point of the loop .",

  "abstract_text": [
    "<S> in [ dr1 ] drinfeld showed that any finite dimensional hopf algebra @xmath0 extends to a quasitriangular hopf algebra @xmath1 , the quantum double of @xmath0 . based on the construction of a </S>",
    "<S> so  called _ diagonal crossed product _ developed by the authors in [ hn ] , we generalize this result to the case of quasi  hopf algebras @xmath0 . as for ordinary hopf algebras , as a vector space </S>",
    "<S> the `` quasi  </S>",
    "<S> quantum double '' @xmath1 is isomorphic to @xmath2 , where @xmath3 denotes the dual of @xmath0 . </S>",
    "<S> we give explicit formulas for the product , the coproduct , the @xmath4matrix and the antipode on @xmath1 and prove that they fulfill drinfeld s axioms of a quasitriangular quasi  </S>",
    "<S> hopf algebra . </S>",
    "<S> in particular @xmath1 becomes an associative algebra containing @xmath5 as a quasi  </S>",
    "<S> hopf subalgebra . on the other hand </S>",
    "<S> , @xmath6 is not a subalgebra of @xmath1 unless the coproduct on @xmath0 is strictly coassociative . </S>",
    "<S> it is shown that the category @xmath7 of finite dimensional representations of @xmath1 coincides with what has been called the double category of @xmath0modules by s. majid [ m2 ] . </S>",
    "<S> thus our construction gives a concrete realization of majid s abstract definition of quasi  </S>",
    "<S> quantum doubles in terms of a tannaka  krein  like reconstruction procedure . </S>",
    "<S> the whole construction is shown to generalize to weak quasi  </S>",
    "<S> hopf algebras with @xmath1 now being linearly isomorphic to a subspace of @xmath2 .    </S>",
    "<S> [ section ] [ df]theorem [ df]lemma [ df]corollary [ df]proposition </S>"
  ]
}
